results.name: Triangle of idempotent numbers binomial(n,k)*k^(n-k), version 2.
comment: The inverse triangle is the signed version 1,-2,1,9,-6,1,.. of triangle A061356. - _Peter Luschny_, Mar 13 2009
T(n,k) is the sum of the products of the cardinality of the blocks (cells) in the set partitions of {1,2,..,n} into exactly k blocks.
Let M = A093375, the exponential Riordan array [(1+x)*exp(x), x], and for k = 0,1,2,... define M(k) to be the lower unit triangular block array
having the k x k identity matrix I_k as the upper left block; in particular, M(0) = M. The present triangle equals the infinite matrix product M(0)*M(1)*M(2)*... - see the Example section. (End)
The Bell transform of n+1. For the definition of the Bell transform see A264428. - _Peter Luschny_, Jan 18 2016
reference: L. Comtet, Advanced Combinatorics, Reidel, 1974, p. 91, #43 and p. 135, [3i'].

example: With the arrays M(k) as defined in the Comments section, the infinite product M(0)*M(1)*M(2)*... begins
mathematica: t = Transpose[ Table[ Range[0, 11]! CoefficientList[ Series[(x Exp[x])^n/n!, {x, 0, 11}], x], {n, 11}]]; Table[ t[[n, k]], {n, 2, 11}, {k, n - 1}] // Flatten (* or simply *)
t[n_, k_] := Binomial[n, k]*k^(n - k); Table[t[n, k], {n, 10}, {k, n}] // Flatten
program: (MAGMA) /* As triangle */ [[Binomial(n,k)*k^(n-k): k in [1..n]]: n in [1.. 15]]; // _Vincenzo Librandi_, Aug 22 2015
# Adds a column 1,0,0,0, ... at the left side of the triangle.
(PARI) for(n=1, 25, for(k=1, n, print1(binomial(n,k)*k^(n-k), ", "))) \\ _G. C. Greubel_, Jan 05 2017
xref: There are 4 versions: A059297-A059300. Diagonals give A001788, A036216, A040075, A050982, A002378, 3*A002417, etc. Row sums are A000248. A093375.
